title: Mordes new story actually explains why Beatrice was in the immortal Bastion
body:
It always striked me as odd that Beatrice was appearantly just hanging out in Noxus and the immortal Bastion with no explanation what she was doing there.

However with Mordes new lore it actually makes a lot of sense for Beatrice to be locked up in the immortal bastion, as Beatrice is a demon of secrets and Mordekaisers big goal is to uncover the secrets of death, so he was likely the one who brought Beatrice to the immortal bastion, hoping that he could use her to gain information about the afterlife and once Morde died again Beatrice simply remained in the immortal bastion(either on her own or she was locked up and couldn't get out).

replies.body:
We kinda already knew that.

Swain found Beatrice in the immortal bastion, and that the immortal bastion was erected by Mordekaiser. Even without explicitly knowing about the iron revenant's search for secrets, we could theorize that he put her there and that she was there for a reason.

What it truly is interesting is what Beatrice actually knows for her to be that valuable and powerful. 

In order to retrieve her, Swain journeyed to the core of the Immortal Bastion. This is apparently described as a very risky and secretive task. 

I highly doubt that this perilous trip consisted in Swain physically finding a secret passage in the basement of the palace and proceeding to avoid a number of traps ala Indiana Jones.

What if at the core of the immortal bastion there were the *gateway for mordekaiser's kingdom of afterlife*? *And Swain literally walked unnoticed among the dead to steal Beatrice directly from Mordekaiser's grasp?* We know Beatrice whispered to a death's door Swain through a crow and proposed him some sort of deal, that I am going to assume included Swain "freeing" her from Mordekaiser servitude. But Swain somehow tricked her in *his own* servitude. This would also explain Beatrice's powers of gathering the secrets of the recently passed away. She could have some sort of connection with the afterlife realm, so that she could talk to souls in the limbo before they faded as described in mordekaiser new story.

Yeah it was obvious that Morde was responsible for Beatrice being there, but we didn't know why he placed her there.
Now we do know why she was there.
Little did you know Swain was the Indiana Jones of Noxus!{{champion:50}}

There is something that is confusing me.

In his new lore.... does Mordekaiser still have any connection to the Shadow Isles, or doesn't he?
In Universe, he is still listed as a Shadow Isles champion, but these are never mentioned in his new lore now. And I remember a Rioter saying that he is unrelated to the Mist.

______________

But **if** Mordekaiser has no ties to the Shadow Isles anymore.... why did they colour code him that way?
Just like how they gave Urgot alot of green details with his rework to emphasise his relation to Zaun now, Mordekaiser is way more in line with other Shadow Isles undeads when it comes to his colours.

This is confusing me, someone help pls.

This is a good question!

Short answer is that Mordekaiser is not a Shadow Isles champion anymore. For updates the champions bios get updated when they go to PBE but their Universe page is updated after they get fully released, which is why you still see Morde listed with Shadow Isles champs.

As to the color question you're pretty much on the money, we just need to take a step further and think more holistically instead of region specific. Morde is a "vengeful spirit" bound to armor and many of the Shadow Isles are also "vengeful spirits" so they are very similar... just in different places in Runeterra.

Which would beg the question is there potentially some unknown connection between what Mordekaiser is attempting and the effects of the Ruination? lol That might muddy the waters more than help but at least I hope that answers your question >. < my brain is a wondrous place and I recognize that sometimes what I say makes sense to me but no one else.

I personally thought Mordekaiser using the undead of the Isles as his starter army until he could get back into the swing of things made him much more interesting of a character, as it juxtaposed his foreign, ancient necromancy against that of the Black Mists, and showed us how much more powerful he was than the all consuming Mists. He wasn't even a Shadow Isles champion in his previous lore, he was just using it as a launch pad for greater things.

And also, just a note to your narrative folks - be careful of the constant shifting of the lore. It's part of what's making the comic book industry start to reel (aside from it being a paper medium), as people don't like having to constantly relearn and re-understand the world that was already fairly well established. It'd almost be better if you guys didn't do lore for high VGU-worthy champions prior to their VGUs, as it's not only double work, but you're also scrapping modernized lore that makes a lot of sense to replace it with brand new modernized lore. Mordekaiser is a good example of this, as his previously updated lore fit pretty seamlessly into the lore and spiderwebbed out to connect a lot of things together.
Please say the second part louder.

Amen! I still try to follow the lore, but the fact that almost half of what I devotedly followed is now non-canon or dubiously canon means that I don't really care, especially when some of the stories both new and old... lack merit. (I'm sorry writers, but Neeko's color story feels implausible on several levels).

the swain's demon, i think

Beatrice was the name of pre-rework Swain's raven (he only had one back then). New Swain was given an in-game joke animation/voice line that refers to Beatrice as a nod to his pre-rework companion, but it probably isn't canon given how far-out and fourth wall-breaking most in-game jokes are. 

Assuming it is canon though, Swain probably just named one of his demon crows Beatrice himself -- but that isn't an indication of the demon's real name by any means, if it even has one. Players just refer to the demon as such nowadays because it's easier that way.
